title: 103_hr82
content: Restoration of deduction for interest on educational loans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 restores the deduction for interest on educational loans, defining a qualified educational loan as any indebtedness provided through a guarantee program. The definition of a "loan" for educational purposes includes indebtedness provided through guarantee programs, by tax-exempt organizations, or under supplemental education programs requiring repayments to the educational institution. The tax benefit for interest on educational loans is phased out based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The loan must be used for qualified educational expenses within a reasonable timeframe. The tax benefit for interest on educational loans is phased out based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The taxable year is reduced by an amount determined by the ratio of the excess of the taxpayer's adjusted gross income over the applicable dollar amount to the phaseout range. For unmarried individuals, the applicable dollar amount is $40,000 with a phaseout range of $15,000, while for joint filers, the applicable dollar amount is different. The tax benefit for interest on educational loans is phased out based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amount is $40,000 with a phaseout range of $15,000 for unmarried individuals, $60,000 with a phaseout range of $30,000 for joint filers, and zero for any other case. The deduction is allowable only for the first 48 months of repayment status. Qualified educational expenses are defined for this purpose. The tax benefit for interest on educational loans is phased out based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The deduction is allowable only for the first 48 months of repayment status and is based on qualified educational expenses. The tax deduction for interest on educational loans is phased out based on adjusted gross income. Qualified tuition and related expenses include reasonable living expenses while away from home. The $40,000 and $60,000 amounts in the deduction are adjusted for inflation. The tax deduction for interest on educational loans is adjusted for inflation based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The tax deduction for interest on educational loans is adjusted for inflation based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1993, but only with respect to loans the first required payment on which is after such date.
